questions.question: Where does the initiation of nerve impulse occur in a spinal motor neuron?

questions.question: What is known as the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit actionpotential after the application of one stimulus?
questions.explanation: The refractory period is the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit actionpotential after the application of one stimulus. It can be absolute or relative.During the rising and much of the falling phases of the spike potential, the neuron is refractory tostimulation. This refractory period is divided into an• Absolute refractory period, corresponding to the period from the time the firing level is reacheduntil repolarization is about one-third complete• Relative refractory period, lasting from this point to the start of after-depolarizationDuring the absolute refractory period, no stimulus, no matter how strong, will not excite thenerve. However, during the relative refractory period, stimuli that are stronger than normal cancause excitation.The absolute refractory period for large myelinated nerve fibers is about 1/2500 second.

questions.question: From where does the relative refractory period start?
questions.explanation: The relative refractory period starts from one-third of repolarization till the start ofafter-depolarization.The refractory period is a period during which another normal action potential cannot be elicitedin an excitable cell.

questions.question: A slowly rising stimulus fails to fire a nerve because of a process known as
questions.explanation: Slowly rising subthreshold currents fail to fire the nerve due to a process called accommodation,which is a type of adaptation.Accommodation is due to inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels. Due to the slow rise ofstimulus, only a few voltage-gated Na+ channels are activated at a time. These few channels areinactivated by the time more channels are activated. So, at no moment, are a sufficient number ofchannels activated to give an action potential.When a membrane is depolarized rapidly, a large number of Na+ channels open at once, and anaction potential is produced.In contrast, decreased response to a long-lasting and sustained suprathreshold stimulus, ingeneral, is called adaptation.

Summation occurs in two ways:•⚫ by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ■bersummations.• by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead totetanization.When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventuallyfuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous,124this is called tetanization.
